channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-3804] HBase gets stuck with "Regions in transition timed out" for .META. and -ROOT-
item.description:
After putting some significant load on the sever (load around of 8 for approximatively 50 minutes) the following starts showing in the logs and then hbase is completely stuck: won't recover without a restart (I copy a large chunk of the master logs before the problem in case it helps; the bottom part about ROOT and META repeats forever):

9000/hbase/.logs/HQSNOSQL01,60020,1303302276146/HQSNOSQL01%3A60020.1303305484717
2011-04-20 06:19:51,228 INFO org.apache.hadoop.hbase.regionserver.wal.SequenceFileLogWriter: Using syncFs – HDFS-200
2011-04-20 06:19:51,228 DEBUG org.apache.hadoop.hbase.regionserver.wal.HLogSplitter: Creating writer path=hdfs://hqsnosq
l01:9000/hbase/Property/69e1f895ca9d6824b409015a9f9c03a3/recovered.edits/0000000000000098012 region=69e1f895ca9d6824b409
015a9f9c03a3

item.summary: HBase gets stuck with "Regions in transition timed out" for .META. and -ROOT-

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: So you have one node? And the region server's session expired? If so, then that's the expected behavior because the master cannot assign those regions.

This sounds like good news; it sounds like the problem would not exist once I move my project to a multi nodes cluster.
Yet I am surprised that this behavior where hbase completely looks up would be expected (even in a single node cluster); can you explain more what is going on and why the single node cluster can't cope with it?

Thanks

Laurent Chavet

So how it works: for some reason your region server died. A region server is what carries and serves the regions (so the data). One thing that's not clear to me is if you are running in "standalone" mode or "pseudo-distributed" mode. If the former, then yeah I agree that it's a bit dumb that it locks up like that because you cannot restart the region server inside the master process. If you were using the latter, then well your region server died and you need to restart it.

What the master does when a node dies is that it splits the write ahead logs (that's what's going on in the beginning of your log) and reassigns the regions. In your case, there's no one to reassign the regions to. The master cannot carry the regions, so it's waiting for a new region server to come in.

On to why the region server died, there should be a hint in the log. Something on the FATAL log level. Probably GC pauses.

BTW the book has this to say on single node clusters: "Do not use this configuration for production nor for evaluating HBase performance."

Thanks very much; that was it.
I am running in "pseudo-distributed" and the region server did die (I need to increase the limit on open files).
It all makes sense to me now; thanks for the very fast answers.
BTW: is there standard way to automatically restart the region severs when they crash or should I write my own small script to deal with that.
Actually do you even think it's a good idea to automatically restart (I might have missed the real problem)?
